section.p: In this activity, we will continue to explore how a change to a function's formula will alter its graph. In particular, we will see the effect of multiplying the output of a function by a constant number.
Remember that if you perform some calculation with the output of a function f, you will be performing that calculation with an expression like f(a).
In this first exercise, you'll practice writing an expression for the output of a function which has been altered.

section.p: Similarly, remember that the number (or expression) inside parentheses, such as the variable a in the expression f(a), always represents the input of the function.
So, if you perform some calculation with the input of a function, you will be performing that calculation on the expression inside the parentheses.

li.p: For a function f(x), what does f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right) calculate?
Answer:
For a function g(x), what does 3\cdot g(5) calculate?
Answer:
Remember that having f(\text{something}) means we are talking about an output.
Remember that g(5) represents the output, when the input is 5.
While it is certainly true that the input x has been divided by 2, the expression f\left(\frac{x}{2}\right) is the output of the function, when the input x has been divided by 2.
Since g(5) represents the output of the function, when the input is 5, then 3\cdot g(5) is just 3 times the output, when the input is 5.

paragraphs.title: Effects on the graph
paragraphs.p: Now let's see how to apply these concepts to the graph of a function.

section.p: First, you will use the graph of a function to complete a table of values by altering the output.

section.p: Next, you will plot points on the graphs of functions where the output has been multiplied by a number.

section.p: In the previous exercise, you plotted points for the functions y = 2f(x) and \frac{1}{2}f(x). This created graphs which were similar to the original function y = f(x), but whose outputs were either twice as large, or half as large as those of f(x).
This makes sense, because multiplying outside of the function f(x) by a number like 2 or \frac{1}{2}, just changes the output values — and the output values are the heights of the points.
In the next two exercises, you will explore how multiplying the output of a function by a number will change the graph.

section.p: Finally, compare the transformation a\cdot f(x) with the transformation f(x) + a which we studied in chapter.

set.member: \text{The transformations a\cdot f(x) and f(x) + a are really the same thing.}
\text{The transformation a\cdot f(x) stretches or compresses the graph vertically, but f(x) + a shifts the graph up or down.}
\text{The transformation a\cdot f(x) shifts the graph up or down, but f(x) + a stretches or compresses the graph vertically.}
\text{The transformation a\cdot f(x) changes the graph vertically, but f(x) + a changes the graph horizontally.}
